turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Laws of Duplicate Bridge.
turn.1: What is meant by playing out of turn?
turn.2: An "opening lead" out of turn (law 54) is perhaps the most frequent infraction.
turn.3: What are some consequences of playing out of turn?
turn.4: If the wrong defender makes the opening lead, the to-be-declarer has the following options:  Unauthorized information (UI) (law 16) is any information that a player obtains by means of:  Reception of unauthorized information is not an infraction "per se".
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: However, the player who ("might have") received it has severe limitation that (s)he may not act on the basis of it (even if the action is reasonable), but must select a "logical alternative" instead.
turn.8: The definition of "logical alternative" is fairly strict, and includes all but practically inadmissible alternative actions.
turn.9: What are some examples of logical alternatives?
turn.10: However, in the (fairly unlikely) event that the logical alternative becomes a successful one rather than the action suggested by the UI, no further redress is given to the non-offending side.
turn.11: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.12: The exception is when the player receives a UI inadvertently, as by overhearing remarks at other tables.
